Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Autotuning for multicore and manycore architectures: an enhanced feedback-driven approach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Achieving a high fraction of peak performance on complex architectures has been a perennial challenge for application developers. The emergence of multicore processors and accelerators has greatly exacerbated this problem. With an increasing number of cores per socket, deep hierarchies of shared and distributed caches, and exascale computing on the horizon, multicore platforms pose unprecedented challenges for software development and application tuning. This research confronts the challenge of multicore and manycore software development by improving automatic performance tuning through improved feedback diagnostics. Autotuning efficiency is achieved through enhanced knowledge of the problem domain, program features and architectural characteristics. To this end, we are developing a set of tools that allow specification, collection and synthesis of tuning related information. This rich set of information is then exploited through novel machine learning models to deliver scalable, portable and sustainable performance on diverse architectures.

In line with this research, we have established, SISTEM, a structured interdisciplinary program for undergraduates that brings together faculty and students from different STEM disciplines to explore cross-cutting research problems in which computational thinking, modeling and simulation play a central role.

The techniques developed as past of this research will have a direct economic impact through saved energy and computation cycles on high-end systems. The improved efficiency of applications will allow researchers to execute large-scale simulations that will enable modeling of complex phenomenon in a broad range of disciplines including medicine, high-energy physics, climate modeling and nanotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Achieving a high fraction of peak performance on complex architectures has been a long standing challenge for application developers. The emergence of multicore processors and heterogeneous architectures has greatly exacerbated this problem. This project was conceived to confront the impending challenge of multicore and manycore software development. Specifically, the research focused on improving autotuning systems in which alternate code variants are generated with tuning parameters and then a heuristic search is invoked with execution time feedback to obtain implementations that yield near-optimal performance.

Research: The research conducted in this project has advanced the state-of-the-art in performance analysis and modeling of HPC applications. The project developed new methods for mining the extensive feedback that can be obtained via hardware performance counters on modern architectures. Data analysis techniques were introduced to analyze and synthesize performance counter data for meaningful characterization of program behavior. These techniques provided new insight as to how applications interact with the underlying hardware components and how that interaction affects the end performance and energy  efficiency. The insights gained from the analyses were incorporated into a series of Machine Learning driven performance models that were integrated into mainstream compilers and runtime systems, including LLVM. The developed techniques include performance models for GPU register allocation, software prefetching, data movement and organization in heterogeneous memory systems, and task distribution in multicore systems.  

This project also introduced MLTUNE, an end-to-end framework for automatically generating new Machine-Learning based performance heuristics. MLTUNE consists of a tool-chain that automates the workflow for creating data-driven compiler models, including automated mechanisms for sample generation, dynamic feature extraction, feature selection, data labeling, validation and hyper parameter tuning. MLTUNE has been made freely available as open-source software and is maintained and supported by the PI.    

To date, the use of these models have resulted in substantial performance and energy gains on a broad class of applications running on heterogeneous HPC systems. These include applications in physical simulation, graph analytics and operations research.  

Education: This project established an education initiative to prepare STEM students for careers in HPC that require multi-disciplinary perspectives. The program introduced new curriculum at Texas State University in the form of a re-designed CS1 course, a series of teaching modules integrated at various levels of the undergraduate curriculum and an inter-disciplinary graduate course that exposes students to a diverse set of problems that span multiple fields of study in STEM. The enhanced curriculum is complemented with out-of-class training workshops that focus on specific HPC skills. During the span of this project, over one hundred students have enrolled in the program at different levels. Over 50% of these students were from underrepresented groups.
